awd_titl_txt: Integrating Transdisciplinary and Computational Approaches in the Earth Science Curriculum Using Data Visualizations, Scientific Argumentation, and Exploration of Geohazards
awd_abstract_narration:
As a result of the powerful innovation and application of computing in STEM disciplines, the STEM+C program addresses an urgent need for real-world, interdisciplinary, and computational preparation of students from the early grades through high school (preK-12). This project will advance research and development of new transdisciplinary approaches to computational STEM teaching and learning that will integrate computational thinking through data visualizations, the scientific practice of argumentation from evidence, and earth science concepts focused on geohazards. The team will develop a open-source scaffolded programming tool for data visualizations, and two curricular modules on geohazards for middle and high school aligned with Next Generation Science Standards. Integration of computational thinking and science practices will occur as students transform real-world GPS data into manageable and interpretative visualizations using the programming tool and use them as evidence to formulate scientific arguments about predicting the impact of geohazards. The resulting products can serve as exemplars for curriculum developers, researchers, and educators to integrate computational data visualization practices with disciplinary STEM learning, and inform strategies to support teachers and students when implementing these practices. This project is supported by the STEM + Computing Program that advances research and development of interdisciplinary and transdisciplinary approaches to the integration of computing within science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) teaching and learning for preK-12 students in both formal and informal settings. STEM+C supports research on how students learn to think computationally to solve interdisciplinary problems in the STEM fields.

The examination of the integrated geohazard units with the scaffolded programming tool for data visualization will take place in two phases. First, design-based research will be conducted to refine the tool and curriculum modules, develop assessments for students' content learning and argumentation practices, and identify teacher supports necessary for implementing this type of curriculum module in classroom.  Second, a delayed cohort pre-post-test design will investigate the impact of integrating the computational practice of data visualization on student learning. The project will reach 800 students and 12 teachers, and be implemented in a wide range of schools including those that serve underrepresented students in STEM.  Developed products and research findings will be widely disseminated to practitioners, developers, and researchers in the fields of science education, geosciences, educational technology, and learning sciences

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Earthquakes and volcanoes are natural phenomena caused by the movement of tectonic plates on Earth. These powerful events pose risks to people and their property all over the world. Scientists analyze Earth?s clues to make forecasts about when and where they may occur. Their study includes the use of powerful computational tools to filter, analyze, and visualize the high-quality data collected from remote sensors and satellites from around the globe. The work of volcanologists and seismologists who monitor volcanoes and earthquakes can be translated for use in the classroom through an intentional simplification, but not distortion, of their tools and practices. Indeed, not only is the study of geohazards scientifically important, it is also captivating to students. The GeoCode project translated the core computational aspects of practicing scientists to provide middle and high school students with the opportunity to investigate and explain the environmental factors influencing earthquakes and volcanic eruptions, make predictions about when and where they may occur, and assess the impacts of these events on people and their property. 

The GeoCode project was guided by the design principle that technology holds transformative potential for revolutionizing geoscience education. Computational models make it possible for students to experiment with otherwise inaccessible concepts and engage in the authentic practices of modern scientists. The goal of the GeoCode project was to design geoscience modeling software and embed it in curriculum modules for middle and high school Earth science classes. GeoCode focused on two areas: 1) translating the authentic computational methods and tools of scientists to a level suitable for students and 2) synergistically integrating computational thinking and key geoscience learning outcomes by exploring case studies of real-world volcanic and seismic geohazards. The project worked to help students better understand the mechanisms and impacts associated with volcanoes and earthquakes and improve their ability to assess risks, so that they are able to make informed decisions and take appropriate actions by considering their local community?s vulnerability and exposure to potential natural hazards. 

The GeoCode project developed two unique versions of the GeoCoder, a computational modeling tool that allows students to use block code to simulate and visualize the environmental factors influencing volcanic eruptions and seismic events. With the volcano version of the GeoCoder, students use code to set the wind speed, wind direction, and volcanic explosivity (VEI) of an eruption and see the resulting tephra, or volcanic ash, distribution around the volcano. In the seismic version of the GeoCoder, students use code to visualize GPS velocities throughout the West Coast of the United States and simulate the deformation of land around the San Andreas fault in California. These tools are embedded in two separate online curriculum modules that scaffold investigations of real-world volcanic and earthquake phenomena. 

The project also developed research instruments to measure students? knowledge of computational practices and science content understanding. During three years of data collection, over 95 teachers implemented the modules with over 4,300 students both within the U.S. and across the globe. Students significantly improved their knowledge of both computational practices and science concepts after engaging with the GeoCode modules. A study specific to the GeoCode: Volcanic Hazards module identified students? increased sophistication in the use of computers to solve scientific problems and in the inclusion of domain-specific language in students? responses. Through analysis of student observations and predictions of probabilistic models, the project identified certain types of computational model outputs that present learning opportunities through problematization and comparison. In the GeoCode: Seismic Hazards module, the project?s innovative design linking the block code, visualization, and science content helped students to conduct and understand scientific investigations. In addition, students who were best able to make connections between the visualizations and science content had the most sophisticated responses. Using student responses to assessments and surveys, the project developed a novel design framework, which can serve as a blueprint for other Earth science educators working to translate scientists? computational tools, practices, and knowledge for middle and high school students.

The modules and full suite of support materials are available on the Concord Consortium website.
